user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_GenericWrite_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_GenericWrite_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const void *buffer, size_t nbytes, int32 timeout)
{
    int32                           return_code;
    ssize_t                         os_result;
    uint32                          operation;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    return_code = OS_SUCCESS;

    if (nbytes > 0)
    {
        operation = OS_STREAM_STATE_WRITABLE;

        /*
         * If filehandle is set with O_NONBLOCK, then must call select() here.
         *
         * The "selectable" field should be set false for those file handles
         * which the underlying OS does not support select() on.
         *
         * Note that a timeout will not work unless selectable is true.
         */
        if (impl->selectable)
        {
            return_code = OS_SelectSingle_Impl(token, &operation, timeout);
        }

        if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS && (operation & OS_STREAM_STATE_WRITABLE) != 0)
        {
            /* on some system libraries for which the write() argument is not
             * qualified correctly, it needs to be case to a void* here */
            os_result = write(impl->fd, GENERIC_IO_CONST_DATA_CAST buffer, nbytes);
            if (os_result < 0)
            {
                OS_DEBUG("write: %s\n", strerror(errno));
                return_code = OS_ERROR;
            }
            else
            {
                /* type conversion from ssize_t to int32 for return */
                return_code = (int32)os_result;
            }
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_GenericWrite_Impl:
int         fd
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Fragments not reported do not show evidence of being statically unreachable. Declarations and the final return statement are normal and reachable in at least one control-flow path. The assignment return_code = OS_SUCCESS and the initial variable declarations cannot by themselves produce unreachable code. Comment lines and the closing return return_code; are not unreachable-code issues. The fragments listed above are those control-flow points that could be impossible to execute depending on configuration/constants or macro behavior (for example: the table lookup/macros used to obtain impl, the nbytes conditional, the selectable/OS_SelectSingle call, the writable-bit test, the write() call, and the os_result branches). These should be investigated to determine whether any of them are in fact impossible to reach (e.g. due to constant definitions, incorrect macro expansions, or invariants elsewhere in the project). Other code in the function is straightforward and does not present an apparent unreachable-code concern.
